Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2011 01:58PM - edited Sep 25, 2011 02:01PM by Jac53 I've had 7 infusions of Taxotere with Cytoxin in 7 months.  SE, probably from Taxotere, are: 'jelly legs', increasing  fatigue that have both put me in a wheelchair when I leave the house, muscle pain & stiffness, permanently weepy eyes, loss of hair, neuropathy in fingers & toes, vomiting & diarrhea.  I'll take dose 8 then I'm insisting on a break to recover if the doc suggests more chemo.   On the other hand .... all my mets have shrunk and were still shrinking 10 days ago.

Posts.Title: Info: Parenting with Cancer Jac53 Iwillwinthisbattle

Posts.Content: Jac53 wrote: Got this news yesterday after being drained of 2L of pleural fluid.  Tuesday I'm having an op to introduce talc into the cavity as well as a drain/entrance for chemo.  Also, both of my upper arms are large tumours now.   I'll be starting a Phase 1 trial through this drain thingy I'll have in my chest. I'm also anaemic & having a transfusion Tuesday.  The trial is due to finish in a few months with what looks like a possible extension. I think I stopped listening to the onc & trying to understand after the words 'cancer cells extended to pleural cavity'. I thought I was going for my 1st Stable period until the fluid started.   Now I spend a lot of time cuddling my dog & feeling sorry for myself. Anyone with experience of any of this, please send me your info.. Jeannie. "You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough." Posts.Title: New to pleural cavity mets - info? Jac53 Padiddle

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 05:20AM Jac53 wrote: I've just had about 3 weeks of pleural effusion during which I was semi-comatose, then 2 weeks of diarrhoea during that.  It's coming on for 4 weeks of hospital treatment now & I feel in perfect health for the 1st time today. The onc has given me a partial 'talk'.  Can't do much else for me as only a couple of treatments are left available.   The manufacturing firm for the clinical study treatment refused it for me as I'd had diarrhoea & the pleural effusion which have both finished now. Have to tell my daughter today, my son was with me when the onc spoke to me.  I had to state my end of life choices - at what stage do I want treatment to stop & they can let me go.  What level of quality of life do I want to stop treatment at etc. Started Halaven (Erubilin) last Tuesday & waiting for my 2nd dose to be given today. I feel empty & odd as I've never been in this situation before.  I saw the counselor yesterday & she helped me clarify my thoughts a bit more.  I don't feel as if I'm dying.  That's odd.  Thought I'd feel like I was so close to dying.  I'm pretty desperate to get out of hospital & back to my home, dogs & other loved & familiar things. Oh crap!  Life's so unfair, I feel like complaining about it again but still don't know where to go for that & even if I knew I don't think I have the energy for that. Thanks for being there to let me complain.
Posts.Title: New to pleural cavity mets - info? Jac53 Padiddle

Posts.Title: Not making it to 2nd opinion OT tammie bhd1

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2013 01:14PM - edited Sep 25, 2013 01:16PM by Jac53 Thanks all.  I'm on Navelbine now & hope it'll do a good job on my derriere & new tumours.  While in hospital & on permanent bedrest, I was washing my private bits while lying on the bed with one leg straight up in the air to give me room for manoeuvre.  The curtain was pulled around my bed & this was patient wash-time.  A gorgeous ortho surgeon, followed by a gaggle of assistants & students, chose that time to come check up on my broken backside.  It took me ages to think of getting rid of my wash-cloth & closing that leg down.  Stunned by their unexpected visit I suppose.
Posts.Title: 3rd pelvic fracture this year. Any advice? and 'Grumble time'. Jac53 Jac53

Posts.Content: Jac53 wrote: I'm looking for advice to deal with my painful bottom & hopefully improve it's health. I'm taking Calcium daily & VitD every 2 weeks plus Xgeva monthly.  As soon as one fracture heals another appears.  Can't do any physical activities. I'm on the combi of A/A . Is there anything else left apart from staring at the ceiling for a few more weeks. My choir has just folded.  I enjoyed singing in it very much & didn't have to walk to participate. Morale, I call it Emmy during our discussions, is on it's way down although this doesn't last long given my past experiences. Tomorrow, Tuesday 18th, I get my PET Flu scan & bloods results (+ TMs) as well as results of latest pelvic x-ray from the onc & ortho surgeon. How much of the brown stuff can I put up with at one time?  How often can I silently say each day 'Aieeee! my a##e hurts!' when the fracture moves. Jeannie. "You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough." Dx 6/19/1995, 10/15 nodes Dx 2/18/2011, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 7/2/2012, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 04:52AM Jac53 wrote: I'm a Brit living in Belgium.  I ran from the treatment I received in the UK this February & am lucky to have family & friends here in Belgium as well as an excellent health service.  I had my first BC, mastectomy, chemo & radiotherapy in '95. My children were adolescents then.   Dx with stage VI in Feb this year. My liver mets have disappeared with the 8 treatments of chemo I've just finished & all my bone mets have shrunk.  I'm lucky in that I have very little pain & am recovering well from the chemo (but not fast enough!).   A warm welcome to our new members.  Sorry you have the reason for being here whether you are the stage VIer or care giver.   I hope you'll find the support, info & space to rant here that you might need.  Jeannie

Posts.Content: Jac53 wrote: I saw an orthopaedic surgeon yesterday & am still a bit shocked at what I saw on my pelvis & hip scan.  He said my pelvis & 3 lumbar vertebrae are like swiss cheese & that I have a high risk of these vertebrae collapsing and of becoming paralysed from the waist down.  He said that I had an old fracture of my pelvis that had healed very well & I seem particularly good at healing bone problems.  I have a biphosphonate treatment once a month, take a prescription calcium & Vit D pill everyday & take glucosamine chondroitine daily.  I used to be very physically active before the fractured pelvis last February.  The doc says I can start back with Yoga (30 years practise), Aquagym (20 yrs practise) & swimming (lifelong swimmer) but I'm scared.  Hate being scared. Do you have any pertinent info/advice/suggestions for improving my bone health? I'm now terrified of becoming paralysed.  I didn't have a problem with stage 4 Dx after the initial shock but this is scaring me into inaction & a great feeling of vulnerability.  Don't feel I have any controle over this although ... do we really have controle over our lives? Jeannie  Jeannie. "You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough." Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 03:52AM Jac53 wrote: Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness that most frightens us. We ask ourselves, Who am I to be brilliant, gorgeous, talented, fabulous? Actually, who are you not to be? You are a child of God. Your playing small does not serve the world. There is nothing enlightened about shrinking so that other people won't feel insecure around you. We are all meant to shine, as children do. We were born to make manifest the glory of God that is within us. It's not just in some of us; it's in everyone. And as we let our own light shine, we unconsciously give other people permission to do the same. As we are liberated from our own fear, our presence automatically liberates others." What a great idea to bring in sewing projects finished & unfinished.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2012 12:14PM Jac53 wrote: Hi manysunshine, I don't have experience of being completely chair/bed-bound but have had a great deal of pain & difficulty walking from pelic fractures.   Has your mom had a 2nd or 3rd opinion?  In one of the larger cancer centres?   Has she had an onc-surgigical consultation?   Has she been in contact with a Palliative Care team for the pain?  They deal with pain & can intervene early in treatment to prevent pain. There are also methods of pain-controle through stress-reduction type meditation & holistic massage by cancer massage therapist within a team. Others will come along soon with other suggestions for your mom. My best wishes for you & your mom at this difficult time.  I'm sure there is help around to improve her quality of life.

Posts.Content: Jac53 wrote: OUR GREATEST FEAR It is our light not our darkness that most frightens us Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light not our darkness that most frightens us. We ask ourselves, who am I to be brilliant, gorgeous, talented and fabulous? Actually, who are you not to be? Mariane Williamson Jeannie. "You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough." Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 07:25AM Jac53 wrote: I took Claritin the day of the the Neulasta shot & enjoyed the week before the next treatment.  The side effects do end but it feels like they never will.  Take as much care of your body as you can through nutricious food/drinks that you can keep down & skin & nail care.  Hand & foot massages are good if you have a willing massager or can afford a professional.  Hang on in there.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 07:32AM Jac53 wrote: I'm on a Bayer clinical trial for Sorafenib=Nexvar taken with Xeloda.  It's a double-blind trial so I've no idea if I have the medication or the placebo.   So far so good, I only have spotty arms & legs as well as sensitive fingers & heels as side-effects, no idea if they're from the Soferanib or Xeloda.   All costs are covered by Bayer.   Good luck with whatever your choice is.

Posts.Content: Jac53 wrote: On my 2nd Navelbine treat 5 days ago, the Day Hospital onc told me I might have a lump deep in my brain causing problems with my thryroid. Had the PET suitable for that problem last Friday 4th Oct & am waiting for results. Since that 1st treatment I've just realized that I've been sleeping most of my 24 hour day & waking screaming. I didn't realize that the problem was so serious until a friend told me that she'd woken me up when calling me & I was screaming about my children (in their 30s) being kidnapped. My DD has been telling me that I've been doing this more over the past few days. She's spoken to a friend of mine who is supporting her. I'm waiting until my next appointment on Tue 8th in 2 days time. I can still walk & talk. Might this be psychiatric or a physical problem? I've lost access to my emails with google & don't know how to get it back. Jeannie. "You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough." Had this since 4am & I can't breathe properly. Its 8.50pm here at the momement & I have the Navelbine/Day Hospitiale appointment at 2pm tomorrow afternoon. I must have been this scared before but don't remember when. I'd lilke a cuddle.
Posts.Title: Frightening experience Jac53

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 12:04AM Jac53 wrote: Saw the onc. She thinks the waking/screaming is probably due to me taking the maximum dose of morphine. The brain PET is clean so it wasn't due to a brain tumour. The pain is probably from the liver tumour, that's back since this month after 2 years away, as it's on the cusp just under my rib.. Thanks for all your support everyone, I had a scary time & it's good to be able to share this sort of issue. Looks like I'll see my 60th birthday next month. That's been one of my goals.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 04:07AM - edited Mar 5, 2013 04:07AM by Jac53 I have a mouthwash on prescription from the onc that's made-up in the pharmacy.
